11.text:
Here in Britain, we love a cup of tea, and
I’m no exception.

15.text:
In fact, in the UK, we love it so much we
drink

18.text:
one hundred and sixty five million cups of
tea every day!

22.text:
But whether we’re switching on lights, flicking
on the kettle, or turning on the TV,

27.text:
we don’t really think about how the electricity
we’re using gets to our homes.

39.text:
At 11am on Wednesday the 11th August 1999,
millions of people across the UK stopped what

45.text:
they were doing
and went outside to stare up at the sky

48.text: to watch a total solar eclipse passed overhead.

51.text:
This meant a huge drop in the amount of electricity
that we were using.

56.text:
And half an hour later,
when people went back inside to their homes

59.text:
and offices and factories,
the amount of electricity needed shot up again.

64.text:
By three thousand megawatts in fact.
The largest increase we’ve ever seen in

69.text:
the UK.
That’s the equivalent of an extra five million

72.text:
cups of tea.
Today, we’re headed to the place responsible

76.text:
for balancing the supply and demand of electricity
that we use.

84.text:
[Tom] First off, what is the National Grid?
[Duncan] The national grid is sort-of like the motorway

90.text:
network for electricity in the country.
So, behind us on the wall you can see a big

95.text:
wiring diagram
and that shows the whole of the electricity

99.text:
motorway network
running right from Scotland in the north down

102.text: to London and the south coast in the south.

105.text:
And that carries nearly all of the electricity
you use everyday

109.text:
to boil your kettle, to light and heat your
home.

112.text:
So from here we are constantly balancing the
supply of electricity from generators

117.text:
and matching that against the demand we see
across the country.

120.text:
And that demand varies minutes by minute,
day by day,

124.text:
in ways that we can forecast, but in ways
that do change

126.text:
based on the weather and the time of year
and what people are doing.

130.text:
[Tom] So, how do you balance supply and demand?
[Duncan] The British grid system runs at a frequency

134.text:
of 50 hertz
That means the electricity is always pulsing

137.text:
backwards and forwards 50 times a second.
And that’s what puts power into your lights

142.text:
into you cooker, into everything else, that
50 hertz power

146.text:
Now, what actually happens is that if we have
a little bit more generation than demand

150.text:
a little bit more supply than demand
then it speeds up a bit.

153.text:
A bit like you’re going down a hill too
quickly.

155.text:
And it goes to 50.1 hertz, a little bit more.
If we’ve not got quite enough generation,

161.text:
then the speed slows down.
A bit like when you’re peddling uphill on

164.text:
your bike and it’s really hard work.
And we see it just dip down to 49.9 hertz.

168.text:
It’s a tiny little system frequency variation,
you wouldn’t see it at home,

173.text:
but to us it’s all important.
And if we get it wrong then the system frequency

176.text:
will drop a little bit,
then we’ll just have to push a little bit

178.text:
more power in to make sure we get it right.
And it’s a bit like flying a plane in to land,

182.text: You just need to trim it a little bit each way

185.text:
just to keep yourself on track.
And that’s exactly what we’re doing here.

188.text:
[Tom] And in order to keep flying that plane,
the grid draws upon a variety of different

192.text:
energy sources.
This model uses the same method we’ve used

197.text:
for over a century to generate electricity.
Water is heated and turns into steam; that

203.text:
steam turns a turbine,
which turns a generator, to produce the electricity.

215.text:
Coal, gas, biomass, and nuclear power plants
all use this method,

221.text: but with different sources to heat the water.

224.text:
Wind turbines, hydroelectric dams and tidal
barrages also turn a turbine to generate electricity,

233.text:
And finally we have solar panels, which use
the photovoltaic effect.

237.text:
These methods each have their own advantages
and disadvantages.

241.text:
But what percentage of these power sources
do we use day to day?

245.text:
[Duncan] On a typical day, about half the
power we get these days is from burning gas.

249.text:
From gas-fired power stations
Maybe 10 or 15% from nuclear.

254.text:
Most of the rest is coming from renewables
or trading with our neighbouring countries

259.text:
through cables under the sea, through interconnectors.
And then just a little bit from coal.

264.text:
[Tom] We had a few days recently where we
didn’t use any coal power, is that right?

269.text:
[Duncan] That’s right, for us it’s amazingly
exciting and one of those major milestones.

274.text:
This summer just gone we had for the first
time in 130 years

278.text:
we ran the electricity grid without burning
any coal.

281.text:
And I think if you look today, there’s actually
more solar running than there is coal on the

285.text:
grid, even right now.
As that coal closes, it’s quite a small

289.text:
gap to fill.
So we would expect even more renewable to

292.text:
come on.
Of course we might see additional nuclear

295.text:
and we expect to see
additional nuclear coming on over the coming

298.text:
years
And some of those coal stations have converted

301.text:
from burning coal to burning what we call
‘biomass’.

303.text:
And so those power stations will carry on
with a new life.

307.text:
[Tom] Describe for me the flow of electricity
from its source to my kettle

312.text:
[Duncan] Oh yeah, OK, great question. Great
question,

314.text:
because it’s not here is it?
So what happens is that your power will be

318.text:
generated either at a big power station
like at Hinkley Point nuclear power station or one

324.text:
of the other big power stations around the
country.

326.text:
One of those on it's own can feed a whole city, supply
a whole city with power.

329.text:
Or it might be generated at a wind farm,
either at a farm down the road, or out in

336.text:
the sea somewhere of the coast of Britain.
Or it could be at some solar panels.

339.text:
That power feeds into the grid, into the big
motorway network here

344.text:
And then it moves around the grid like water
to where it’s needed.

347.text:
And then it’ll flow from the motorway network,
from the transmission grid here,

351.text:
it flows down into the local distribution
grid in a town or city near you.

355.text:
And it flows down to a big grey box at the
end of your street.

359.text:
And from that grey box it flows out on a single
wire which feeds every single house individually

364.text:
on the street,
under the road up into the middle of the house

367.text:
probably to a fuse box.
And then from that fuse box it goes out into

371.text:
a little ring,
which is in the wall all the way around the

373.text:
house,
all the way around to the kettle socket probably

376.text:
halfway up the wall in your kitchen.
And then out of that into the kettle.

381.text:
And obviously it only goes into the kettle
when it’s turned on.

383.text:
[Bleep]
So, we know how National Grid manages electricity,

388.text:
but what happens when a large group of people
cause a simultaneous surge in electricity

392.text:
demand
after watching an eclipse or making a cup

396.text: of tea after their favourite TV show?

398.text:
[Duncan] We see a huge surge for power just
at the end of those TV programmes, just as

403.text:
the adverts come on.
We know that's happening, we’ve got a TV in

407.text:
here we will watch as well,
and we look at how interesting and exciting

410.text:
the TV programme is going to be.
And if we know that loads of people are going

414.text:
to sit down and watch it
we’ll get extra power ready so that at the

417.text:
end of the programme we can push it all in
and just match off against demand.

421.text:
If we didn’t do it, the system frequency
would fall.

424.text:
[Tom] So, you’ve got the energy on standby.
Is that stored somewhere?

428.text:
Or are you switching somewhere on? How do
you communicate with power stations to say

432.text:
what you need?
[Duncan] What we’ll do, is we’ll warn

436.text:
people that we might want to use them,
and some of the power stations we can get

439.text:
them ready so that they’re ready to go in
seconds.

441.text:
And big example of that is the pump storage
stations.

445.text:
So pump storage power is where you have a
big lake at the top of a mountain and a big

449.text:
lake at the bottom.
Almost like a bath, you can empty the top

452.text:
lake down a tube,
through an electricity generator, and then

455.text:
into the bottom lake.
And we have several really large pump storage

458.text:
stations around the country.
And then just as a TV programme finishes,

462.text:
you pull the plug of the top lake,
all the water comes rushing down the hill,

465.text:
hits the turbine,
we get huge bursts of electrical power in

468.text:
10, 15, 20 seconds.
Then that surges into the grid and helps meet

473.text:
that big pickup in demand.
And the great thing that we have is that electricity

477.text:
pretty much travels as fast as you can imagine,
almost at the speed of light. So it can go

483.text:
from one power station, it spreads all around
the country

486.text: in an instant. As fast as you can think.

488.text:
[Tom] The electricity available at our fingertips
is instantaneous and seemingly infinite.

494.text:
But perhaps the next time you make a cup of
tea, have a think about the dynamic

499.text:
but unseen system of technology and people
behind that power;

504.text:
and the thousands of others simultaneously
making their own hot cup of tea.
